title: Asdivine Hearts: Back to business!
text: A looong time ago, I started Asdivine Hearts, and polished offa good half of the game; and just a couple of days ago, my gaming instinctclaimed the other half. I obviously complied, because who am I to say no to thegaming instinct?Â Â Â Â Ten hours later, AH is done and dusted. Or not so much,actually; I only witnessed Stellaâ€™s Ending, and didnâ€™t feel the need to reloadClear Data to watch the other outcomes. Iâ€™ll be honest: the harem element leftme cold, and even annoyed me at times. As far as the narrative is concerned, Idefinitely prefer Bond of the Skies, whose story and characterinteractions were both less intrusive and more touching.Â Â Â Â Fortunately, AH is entirely redeemed by its huge focus ongrinding, and its overall grinding-friendliness. Gosh, does this game know howto make a grinding fiend happy! Not only does it give you excellent reasonsto grind, but it also gives you convenient ways to grind:Â Â Â â€” Thereasons: Apart from the thrill of reaching L.99, the main incentive to grindlike a beast is the Magic system. In a nutshell: Magic comes in three forms,namely Light, Shadow and Void. Party members learn one of the threeâ€œnaturallyâ€, and the other two by equipping specific crystals; this means thatyou can have all characters master all types of magic. But wait, thatâ€™s notall: wielding all three types at once grants you access to specific spells thatinclude party heal, meaning that your whole party can be potential Healers. Ifyou put in the grind, that is!Â Â Â Â â€” Theways: Luckily, AH gives you everything you need to grind painlessly. Thegame world kindly provides two spots (see pictures below) teeming with metalfoes that, in true Dragon Quest fashion, give you a crap ton of XP. Youcan also max up the effect of your grinding sessions by using Hearty Peels andHearty Fruits, two items that double the amount of XP and SP reaped from afight. Then you have the ultimate grinding facilitator: the Attract Jewel, whichtriggers a battle for every step taken. Perfect for your late game grinding sessions!Â Â Â Grinding becomes really tedious in the late stages, as theamount of XP needed to gain levels becomes absurdly enormous; but fortunately,reaching the big 99 is by no means necessary to beat the final boss in easymode; although I peaked at Lv.95, that final showdown was a cakewalk. Do Iregret grinding so much? Why, not at all! Grinding is a pleasure in and ofitself for me, you know dat.Â Â Long story short: I spent a lovely time with Asdivine Hearts,and I totally donâ€™t regret buying the Asdivine physical collection forthe Switch. And thus my love story with Kemco continues!

title: Fire Emblem Engage: Should I play or should I pawn?
text: After some five hours spent on Engage, Iâ€™m really torn aboutsoldiering on or not; so much so that I shelved the game under further notice â€” or, in that case, a firm decision from my gaming instinct. Thereare many things I love in Engage, but there are just as many things Idespise; and Iâ€™m gonna try to sort out these feelings by jotting them downhere.Â Â Â TheGood: â€” Theart style! Not gonna lie: the character design and cover art were the firstthings that caught my eye, and they immediately made me immensely partialtowards Engage. I cannot find words to express how much I love thatcombination of blue, red and white in Alearâ€™s design (Iâ€™m French, so obviouslythat specific mix is gonna tug at my heartstrings), and how much I dig the sheer brilliance ofMika Pikazoâ€™s work on colours. Art direction very seldom plays a part in myliking a game, but it totally does as far as Engage is concerned.Â Â â€” Hugefocus on battling! Now thatâ€™s something that plays a huge part in myliking a game; and Engage is more than happy to indulge me. First, nocutscene is sacred in that game, as they can all be skipped. Secondly,enemy phase in battles can be bypassed entirely, and battle animations can beturned off. Thirdly, non-battling gameplay elements can be cut to a bareminimum. For instance: after every battle, you get to chat with your units onthe cleared battlefield, and reap â€˜Bond Pointsâ€™, an in-game currency, as you doso. Say youâ€™re in an Elvis mood and want a little less conversation, a littlemore action please? Feel free to exit the scene and move on to the next battle,as the game will kindly grant you every Bond Points youâ€™d have reaped throughchit-chatting!Â Â Â TheBad: â€”Â  Grinding is too tedious! Engageoffers optional battles for the level-grinders amongst us; but these battlesare routinely harder than story battles. Thatâ€™s not how it should work,dang it! This is a breach of all non-written grinding rules since the dawn ofRPG!Â Â Â â€” Battlesare too strategic! Am I really blaming an SPRG for being strategic?Err, not really. What Iâ€™m saying is that Engageâ€™s battles are simply toochallenging for me â€” even in Normal mode. For one thing, the number offoes on each map is simply astounding; youâ€™re outnumbered as a rule, in everysingle battle. For another, battles are really just plain hard. Take thechapter 8 battle, for instance: you have to use a ballista and quellwaves of Pegasus Knights coming at you every turn! It should surprise no onethat I threw the towel at the beginning of that battle, and havenâ€™t touched thegame since.Â Â Â Thebottom line is that Engage doesnâ€™t accommodate my tried-and-tested wayof playing Fire Emblem. I usually grind as much as I can, rollwith the strongest units, and go at opponents without worrying too much aboutstrengths and weaknesses and unit type complementarity; and it turns out thatthis way of playing is difficult to pull off in Engage. Here, you haveto worry about weapon and unit type complementarity and plan every movecarefully, lest you be swarmed and overpowered by the opposition.Â Â Yup, I really love my girl Alear.Â Thequestion now is: can I find a way to make Engage work for me? There is alot of goodness to be salvaged in that game, and I must admit itâ€™s still kindapulling at me as Iâ€™m writing this. If only I could find an efficient way togrind, and maybe strategize moreâ€¦ I mean, some players are soloing the game inMaddening mode; surely it shouldnâ€™t be so hard to wrap my head about whateverstrategizing is needed to progress smoothly in Normal mode, should it? At any rate, Engage is shelved until my gaming instinct decides its fate.

title: Gaming, a Lady and I
text: Hullo, dear fellow gamers! Way back when I launched ThatExtra Level, I also started following a couple of gaming blogs that struckmy fancy. I still follow them to this day; one of these blogs is LadiesGamers,then known as A Lady and Gaming. LadiesGamers changed a lot over the years,going from a cosy, tiny blog to a huge site full to the brim with content andactivity; one thing that never changed, though, is the presence of Lady YvonneVan Geloven at the helm. Itâ€™s now time to invite her for a revealing gaminginterview!Â Â Â Hello, dear Yvonne! Iâ€™m so glad to have you here, afterall these years! First thing I must ask you is: how did your gaming journeystart? The more details, the better!Â Â Thank you for having me, Isleif! Itâ€™s been quite some timesince we first met on the internet highway, when I found your blog had linkedto my blog. Isnâ€™t it special, how we never met in real life, but kept incontact? Itâ€™s all based on our love of gaming, apparently a strong love whenyou find it late in life, like I have.Â Â So, you asked how my gaming journey startedâ€¦ Talking aboutthat, I always feel like Sophia from the Golden Girls. Picture thisâ€¦. It wasthe year 2006. I was 42 years old and had a little girl of 7 years old. We hadgotten her a Nintendo DS, at first with Nintendogs, the Spring before.But now it was summer holiday and she was free from school. As there was onlyso much time she could spend with her virtual dogs, I promised her a newgame.Â Â I didnâ€™t know anything about games though. She had a coupleof Gameboy Advance games of the platforming kind, that didnâ€™t interest me inthe slightest. And I had played Zelda Windwaker with my husband on ourGamecube, but I was very much content to watch him play. It never occurred tome to be interested in a game for myself. Anyway, back to the store. Knowingnothing about games we picked her new game purely based on the cover: AnimalCrossing Wild World.Â Â As we are Dutch, English isnâ€™t our first language, and mydaughter couldnâ€™t read it. This made for some lovely mother-daughter time,sitting on the couch playing together. We started the town, met Tom Nook andgot all kinds of chores. After a while, she got a bit bored at picking upshells and planting flowers, as thereâ€™s only so much you can do in the firstdays. So, she went off to go do something else and I did what so many mothersdo: I decided to work on it, for her.Â Â Yeahâ€¦rightâ€¦that ended up not being so much for her. I lovedit, couldn't stop playing. And when she went away in the weekend for asleepover I missed the town (and the DS) so much! Thatâ€™s when I decided to splurgeand buy a device and the game for myself. And that was the beginning of it all!The town of Bearpath was born, and it kept me glued to the screen for 1,5years. Every single day, as you have to keep on top of it in Animal Crossing.And what made Animal Crossing even more brilliant? Playing online, visitingeach otherâ€™s towns and chatting together in a group especially for grownup fansof AC.Â Â Â What does gaming bring to your life? Do you feel itâ€™ssomething unique that nothing else can provide?Â Â Thatâ€™s a difficult question. When I was younger, before Ihad my daughter, I was very much into reading and gardening. Had my own littlegreenhouse and watched every episode of Gardeners World on the BBC. Thegardening centre was my favourite place to be, but in hindsight I can see I wasmainly drawn to the sense of discovery. Finding new plants, growing my own fromseed, making arrangements in hanging baskets. Trying to find a special speciesthat Gardeners World had shown. Of course, seeing them in my own garden was thebest feeling, but even then I wasnâ€™t much into the constant weeding and tidyingthings. And somehow, it never seemed to turn out like Alan Titchmarch had shownon tv. Weeds were a constant, and no matter how diligently I tried to subduethem, they always won in the end.Â Â I gave that up when my daughter was born. As every motherwill recognize, I had a serious lack of time to spend on hobbies, especiallysince I also had a job. The only pastime that stayed was reading, as itâ€™seasier to do for half an hour before you turn off the light at night. Readingabout other people's lives, unravelling mysteries and losing myself in a goodfantasy story was always lovely.Â Â Gaming gives me that same feeling of adventure, ofdiscovery and exploration, finding new things and meeting new characters.Thatâ€™s what I love the most. In a sense, games are my books turned into visualadventures. Itâ€™s the right hobby for the right time in my life. And it providedme with friends all over the globe. Something my other hobbies havenâ€™t done forme. Maybe thatâ€™s what is most unique about it: finding like-minded people andkeeping the contact going. Turning from talking about just games to becoming apart of each otherâ€™s lives.Â Â Whatâ€™s your favourite gaming era? Is there a specificsystem, type of game or gaming period youâ€™d like to explore more?Â My favourite gaming era is always the last era. Iâ€™m notinto retro gaming, and I honestly donâ€™t know why Iâ€™d settle for lesser graphicswhen games can be so beautiful these days. For example, I never went back toolder Animal Crossing games. I always play the last one on Switch, neverreturning to Wild World or the GameCube version.Â Â You could say my main draw in a game is the graphics, butitâ€™s a combination of my favourite genre and the graphics. I can honestly enjoythe scenery in a game like Atelier Ryza or Breath of the Wild somuch. Just standing at the top of a hill in Hyrule while the sun is coming upand a wistful tune playsâ€¦.talk about a special moment!Â What do you think of the current gaming landscape?Â Â I think thereâ€™s never been a better time to be a gamer. Thelandscape is diverse, my favourite genres are finally getting the attentionthey deserve. And gaming isnâ€™t something for young adult males onlyanymore.Â Â What is your favourite gaming genre, and what do you lovein that genre?Â Well, there are several. I love simulation games likeAnimal Crossing, farming games like Story of Seasons and turn based RPG likethe Persona games. And whatâ€™s even better: combinations of those farming,crafting, RPG sims. I donâ€™t like pressure in games, timers and action-basedfighting where I need to be on my toes constantly. Relaxing while playing isimportant to me, and I love me some cute colourful graphics as well.Â Â Iâ€™ve mentioned Breath of the Wild already: normallyIâ€™m not a big Zelda gamer, I always have trouble finding out what to donext in the normal Zelda games. But the open world and the vastness ofthe world really struck a chord with me. I think I must be the only gamerthatâ€™s enthusiast about the game for all the wrong reasons! I never evenmastered the flurry attack or beat the big monsters.Â Could you tell us a funny anecdote related to your gamingcareer? It can be anything!Â Â Before COVID struck, I had the good fortune to be invitedto the pre-E3 events of Nintendo Benelux. Representing LadiesGamers of course.Though I was very chuffed to be included, and went there straight from work. Asluck had it, it was across the road where my office was, where I work in mydaytime job. I donâ€™t think I have ever felt so out of place. Can you imagineme, an older lady in my business attire straight from the office. And then theother people: young, very casually clothed, some with colourful hair orpiercings and tattoos. Or just what you would expect in a stereotype nerdy gamer.And aside from me feeling out of place, I could clearly see that the otherswere thinking what on earth I was doing there. The next time I went I broughtmy daughter with me and made sure I was dressed to fit in just a littlemore!Â Â Last but not least, can you tell me five of your favouritegames, and why you love them?Â Â Â My absolute favourite of all times is Animal Crossing.And as the last instalment has so many improvements, New Horizons is the bestat the moment. The laid-back gameplay, thereâ€™s so much to do and to collect andthe way you can get as creative as you want to be. It looks amazing, and Iâ€™vealways loved how for example all appliances really work. But the reason I lovethis series best is the way you can share in the fun with friends. It hasgotten me some very good friends across the globe over the years.Â My second choice is the Atelier series, and heretoo, Iâ€™d like to recommend the last instalments best. Atelier Ryza 2 isabsolutely amazing, as is Atelier Sophie 2. Combining the best ofsynthesizing, exploring, gathering and turn based battles is absolutely perfectfor me.Â Â Third must be the Story of Seasons series, and thelast game Pioneers of Olive Town. Farming, mining, crafting, socializingwith the characters in town. I love it, though I must confess that thereâ€™salways a moment where I feel that enough is enough. When I feel like Iâ€™mturning into a production factory, itâ€™s time to step back.Â Â The Legend of Zelda - Breath of theWild isfourth. Maybe a title you wouldnâ€™t expect on my list, but this game reallystole my heart. Sometimes you just have to hear the music making you want todive right back in. Iâ€™m awful at the fighting, Iâ€™ve never managed to get togrips with the Flurry Attack. But the feeling of climbing the next mountain andstanding there watching the sunrise to the beautiful music score is so verypowerful. I love it for its exploration!Â Fifth place is a hard choice for me. I feel that I shouldmention indie games in general. Over the years of reviewing them for LadiesGamersI feel there are so many gems made by small studios. Not the big blockbusters,but passion projects that ask us for funding on Kickstarter to help make theirvision of a game come true. Iâ€™ve backed quite a few, and itâ€™s been a nicesurprise every time one was ready for release.Â Â Â Now that covered the gaming side, letâ€™s move on to theblogging! Can you tell us what kickstarted your blogging journey? Every detailis welcome!Â When I was younger, I had dreams of someday being apublishing writer. I even started my own book but didnâ€™t get much further thana couple of chapters. When I found my gaming passion and couldnâ€™t really talkabout it with people in real life, the writing about it came easily. After all,if I wanted to chat about my passion to friends and family, they all looked atme as if Iâ€™d lost my marbles. Writing about it was easier, and there were acouple of good friends Iâ€™d found online who were willing to read what Iwrote.Â Â It started out with thoughts about my latest game I wantedto put onto my computer screen, so Iâ€™d have no trouble picking the game upagain if I returned to it in the future. With that, the first version of myblogging adventure started. All this led to my A Lady and Gaming blog that Istarted in 2014.Â Â We all know blogging requires a lot of dedication andendurance, even when you love it. Were there ever times when you consideredtaking a long break, or even stopping? If yes, how did you manage to overcomethese roadblocks?Â Â This may sound very strange but no, I never had thathappen. The thing is, I donâ€™t put any pressure on myself. Especially in thosefirst years when I filled the pages alone, I wrote because it gave me positiveenergy. If I didnâ€™t feel like writing, I didnâ€™t. No problem and no need to feelbad. But most of the time thoughts about gaming jumbled about in my head andthey wanted out. Maybe because in real life I had a very different job as afinance controller. Much more down to earth, analytic, logical and some wouldsay boring. Writing about my hobby could be done anywhere, even during my lunchbreak at work! So in short, no pressure and just letting the words flow wheninspiration hit!Â Â LadiesGamers sure changed a lot over time! What made youwant to bring new writers in? Do you plan more evolutions for yourbaby?Â Can you tell me five of your favourite gaming blogs, and why youlove them?Â Â Youâ€™re right, it has changed. A fellow writer I met throughblogging, who sadly passed away a few years ago, asked if I would review somegames for him. He had gotten some review codes, but hated reviewing gameshimself. We agreed he would publish the reviews first, and my renamed site,LadiesGamers, could publish it a while later. Eventually though the codes keptcoming and I couldnâ€™t handle it alone. This made me think I needed to invitepeople to write with me and in 2017 the first writer joined me.Â Â Nowadays, LadiesGamers is going strong and grows everyyear. At any one time, we have a team of 8 people who all work on reviews andarticles as a hobby as LadiesGamers doesnâ€™t have any source of income. I saywe, as Paula, who Iâ€™ve known since 2016, has joined me in managing the site. Itreally is too big now to run alone, as I also have a full time job. Plus, itâ€™smuch more fun working on it together. We try to keep the site advert free and have a Patreon pageto generate a bit of income. And I hope, in future, that we can keep it advertfree and a safe, restful and colourful haven.Â Aside from keeping an eye on your blog, I donâ€™t follow manyblogs anymore. Only Mattâ€™s Nintendobound. Yours are the only two that remained,somehow most of the blogs that I followed when I started out have stopped!Â A question to sum them all up: do you feel gaming andblogging made your life better, and how? ^^Â It certainly did! It gives me positive energy, Iâ€™ve madegood friends because of it and I hope Iâ€™ll keep on playing and writing foryears to come.

title: Gaming musings: Fleeting Firm Feelings
text: Heythere, dear fellow gamers! Hope youâ€™re doing fine, and doing your stuff likethereâ€™s no tomorrow. As for me, things are clearing up at long last; the tricky situation that was robbing me of my beloved autonomy is about to be resolved, which should grant me some welcome time and energy tofinish the New Classic project and start the building of my website. On top ofthat, Iâ€™m gaming like the wind and enjoying it tremendously, and plenty ofappetizing games are hitting the shelves. But enough with the pleasantries;letâ€™s tackle this postâ€™s main subject!Â As youknow, my gaming instinct is a reliable compass that never failed me, a beaconthat guided me flawlessly through my many decades of gaming. Still, even themost perfect tool can falter sometimes; and it so happens that my trustworthygaming instinct isnâ€™t 100% right in all circumstances. This is precisely what Idubbed â€˜Fleeting Firm Feelingsâ€™; thatâ€™s an explicit enough name, and it meansthat my gaming instinctâ€™s initial feelings about a game are sometimesoverturned â€” by none other than my gaming instinct itself. Â Inpractice, 3F unfolds in three main ways: Â â€” FromGood to Gone: I have a massive crush on a game, only to forget it entirelya couple of days or weeks later.â€” FromFair to Good: I deem a game merely acceptable, only to have it grow on meover the next days or weeks.â€” FromGone to Good: I dismiss a game entirely, only to have it coming back andhaunting me a couple of days or weeks later.Â Â As youmay imagine, the New Classics project is the perfect ground for 3F; the veryact of playing a short time and relying solely on my gaming instinctâ€™ immediateimpressions generated a number of occurrences of 3F already â€” and will probablygenerate some more before Iâ€™m through with the whole endeavour. One of theseoccurrences is none other than a Switch game Iâ€™m currently playing and lovingto pieces, a couple of weeks after swearing it off in my New Classics reports â€”but more on that particular game later! For now, suffice it to say that my subcollectionsare not quite set in stone yet; before I start pawning my discarded games, Iâ€™llcheck carefully for any Good to Gone or Gone to Good occurrences. Jeez, acollectorâ€™s work is never done indeed! Â On a moregeneral note, Iâ€™m seriously starting to wonder if I wonâ€™t simply keep nearlyall my games â€” New Classics as well as rejects. The thing is, Iâ€™mrealising now that the New Classics project was first and last a matter ofsetting priorities and freeing my mind from backlog pressure; now that the deedis nearly done, getting physically rid of games that didnâ€™t make the cutdoesnâ€™t feel as urgent. Keeping most of the rejects wonâ€™t take a lot of room,as I got rid of all plastic cases years ago; and pawning my games wonâ€™t bringme a lot of moneys anyways, as weâ€™re dealing with loose cartridges and UMD. Ofcourse, some games will be disposed of, and that would be thegames I really loathe â€” I donâ€™t think any amount of time will make mefall in love with the Disgaea series, for instance. Â Longstory short: I wanna keep all my options open, and my beloved Collection ascomplete and replete as possible, for the sake of my gaming pleasure andfuture. I may end up never touching the rejects I keep, but that doesnâ€™tmatter; what matters is to gain as much freedom to play as I want, whilebeing firmly aware of my gaming preferences and favourite games. Tackling theNew Classics project was absolutely vital to my gaming enjoyment; I feel atpeace now, and I can keep playing and collecting in a more relaxed, carefreeway. Happy gaming days ahead!

title: Dabbling in Demos: GrimGrimoire OnceMore
text: GrimGrimoire OnceMore is aSwitch remaster of a PS2 game co-developed by Vanillaware and Nippon IchiSoftware. That makes two potential reasons to dislike it; namely Vanillawareand NIS, as most offerings from these two didnâ€™t click with me at all (more onthat in former New Classics reports). Still, Vanillaware and NIS pale incomparison to my main, and actual, reason to dislike GGOM. Weâ€™re dealing with an RTS game; and as you know, I really donâ€™t fancy RTS.Â Â Â  I canacknowledge the sheer originality of a 2D side-scrolling RTS, and howground-breaking it was to get such a game on a console back in the days;however, Iâ€™m long done playing as a gaming historian. I play now as a gamer whowants to have fun, and I donâ€™t have fun playing GGOM. Itâ€™s not a horrible game, mind you; the controls areserviceable, the graphics are gorgeous, cutscenes can be skipped and action canbe sped up. I tried the tutorial earnestly, and even kinda enjoyed it at first;however, I was quickly overwhelmed by the number of tasks to manage at once. Byâ€˜quicklyâ€™, I mean right from the second battle; I had to summon Fairies andmove them to attack foes, while keeping an eye on my already deployed Fairiesand Elves; and that proved too much for the multitasker I am not.Â Â Apartfrom my not fancying RTS, Iâ€™m seriously starting to wonder if I donâ€™t have aninstinctive dislike of all things PS2. I mean, this is the fourth PS2 remake Idislike, after Okami, Psyvariar Delta and Dragon Quest VIII; and you know what they say â€” once ishappenstance, twice is coincidence, etc. Given how remakes of games from formergames are flooding the Switch now, I may encounter another PS2 remake sooner orlater; if/when this happens, Iâ€™ll check the game carefully, or play the demo ifit exists. And since Iâ€™m mentioning demos â€” onto the next one!

title: Dabbling in Demos: Bayonetta Origins â€“ Cereza and the Lost Demon
text: This gameis the work of Platinum Games, and it stars a younger version of Cereza, theuber-badass and gorgeous Umbra Witch from Bayonetta; yet anybodyexpecting anything even remotely close to, well, Bayonetta, is in for asore disappointment.Â Â Â Thatâ€™snot to say that Cereza is a bad game; in fact, itâ€™s a truly excellentgame, and itâ€™s on its way to becoming a welcome addition to The Collection â€” anda New Classic of mine, providing that the gameplay remains as fulfilling as inthe demo. I wonâ€™t elaborate on the splendid graphics and unique atmosphere,because anybody with a functioning pair of retinas can plainly see all thegoodness Cereza has to offer on that front; instead, Iâ€™ll rave about thegameplay, the controls, and the character chemistry.Â Â So,gameplay: weâ€™re dealing with an action-adventure game, and a rather deliberateone at that â€” told you this was no Bayonetta. Little Cereza starts thegame on her own, but is soon joined by the titular Lost Demon, who winds uppossessing Cerezaâ€™s stuffed cat toy Cheshire. Both Cereza and Cheshire boastunique abilities, and can combine them in various ways to progress; as you mayguess, that combination of abilities forms the core of Cerezaâ€™sgameplay. You have to move the characters sometimes together, sometimesseparately; this could have been a recipe for controls disaster, but itâ€™sdiabolically well-handled and ends up being incredibly satisfying instead. Welldone, Platinum Games!Â Â Â HandlingCereza and Cheshire together doesnâ€™t just feel fulfilling in terms of controlsand physics; it also creates a unique emotion I've never felt while playing a game. The pair literally cannot progress without eachother; and that common vulnerability is echoed in the playerâ€™s experience â€”because you cannot progress either as long as you donâ€™t find the rightway to combine their abilities. As a result, the bond between them is not justa narrative element; itâ€™s also a gameplay element that you get to experienceover and over. I can only imagine that bond growing more and more potentand tangible, as the gameplay becomes more intricate and you get to deepen yourmastery of Cerezaâ€™s and Cheshireâ€™s abilities.Â Â Longstory short: I loved that first bite of Cereza, and I very much wannaplay the full thing. And now, on to the next demo! ^^

title: Atelier Firis DX: My life as an explorer
text: Or not somuch, actually. After 15 hours of intense and satisfying play, Iâ€™m done withthe grand alchemy test I was given as a goal at the beginning of the game; andincidentally, Iâ€™m done with the game as well, even though unroamed areas andunfulfilled side quests are still aplenty. I knew this would happen, mind you;and I started playing while anticipating that I would lose all will to playafter I was done with the test. I did lose all will to play all right â€” with abit of help from Gust, who decided to make the credits roll after the test. Youknow that â€˜rolling creditsâ€™ means â€˜next game please!â€™ to me; and that pavlovianconditioning didnâ€™t fail to trigger this time around.Â Â Â Â I played Atelier Firis in a trance, over a grand tally of fourdays and as many playing sessions. I would be hard-pressed to chastise it aftergorging on it so shamelessly â€” and yet, this is exactlywhat Iâ€™m gonna do. See, that gameâ€™s subtitle shouldnâ€™t be â€œThe Alchemist andthe Mysterious Journeyâ€; it should be â€œCognitive Dissonance Much?â€, or â€œLook atthat Yummy Cake yet Donâ€™t You Dare Taking a Bite!â€.Â Â Â Hereâ€™sthe problem in a nutshell: Atelier Firis gives you a whole world toexplore, a wealth of material to forage, plenty of characters to get close to,a myriad of quests to fulfilâ€¦ along with a super-stringent, non-negotiabledeadline that forces you to keep an eye on the passing of days at all times andto run towards your objective at breakneck speed. Forget about losing yourselfin alchemy, exploration and fighting; you can do that all right, but only afteryou pass that darn alchemy exam.Â Â Â I cannothelp but question the logic of that whole design. Whatâ€™s the point of havingsuch a wide and enticing game world, only to curtail the playerâ€™s ability toexplore it to their heartâ€™s content? I know I would have played AtelierFiris very differently without a time limit â€” in fact, I would probably beplaying it still, not writing about it. I would be exploring every nookand cranny of every single area, fighting like a beast, and synthesizing likethe windâ€¦ (wistful sigh)Â Â Â Mind you,the alchemy test is not even that thrilling of a goal either. I went there totest the waters, and ended up passing without really trying. The first part ofthe test is a multiple-choice quiz about all things alchemy; my haphazardanswers landed me a tally of 11/20. Then, I had to synthesize the best item Icould; I went with a mere Bomb, because it was the only item I had craftedenough to get a Platinum Star synthesis level; my toiling at the cauldronproduced a Bomb with a quality value of 53. Then, I had to damage a Puniwith 9999 HP; I threw a Lightning Crystal at it, and did 149 damage. Then, Ihad to fight Ilmeria; and as I was a puny lv.15 against her lv.25, shethoroughly mopped the floor with me.Â Â Â I thoughtfor sure I would fail miserably after such a lacklustre performance on allfronts; but colour me flabbergasted, I actually passed! Did Momâ€™s lovinglyhand-sewn outfit boost my luck, or did the exam committee take pity on me? Oris that alchemy test just really easy, a mere formality to mark the end of themain game? I donâ€™t know, and I donâ€™t really care right now.Â Â Â Â Technically,Atelier Firis wouldnâ€™t make the cut as a New Classic on its own. I had ablast playing it, that I cannot deny; but I had ten times more of a blastplaying Sophie, which I deem better on all fronts bar the openness ofthe game world. But it so happens that I own Firis as part of theAtelier Mysterious Trilogy Deluxe Pack for the Switch; itâ€™s on thecartridge anyway, which saves me the hassle of deciding whether I keep it ornot. And I can always replay it later if my gaming instinct claims it â€”win-win!Â Â I cannot say for sure if I'll ever replay Atelier Firis; what I know for sure, on the other hand, is that I've written enough about it for now. I'll see you soon with more gaming goodness, dear fellow gamers; keep doing yourthing, and take care!

title: Dabbling in Demos: Gal Guardians â€“ Demon Purge
text: I donâ€™treally know why I downloaded that demo, to be honest. I mean, Iâ€™ve never founda Metroidvania that suited me; and the only reason Iâ€™ve not yet renounced thegenre as a whole is my hopeless, never-dying gaming optimism. Still, I didnâ€™thave much hope for Gal Guardians; in fact, I fully expected to getbored upon a few minutes of play.Â Â Â As youmay have guessed already, things didnâ€™t turn this way at all. Not onlydid I polish off the whole demo, but I was also left seriously hooked andcraving for more â€” so much so that I actually replayed the whole thing severaltimes! Needless to say, GG joined my Coveted Game List faster thanyou can say â€˜vade retroâ€™.Â Â Â So, whatmade me so utterly smitten, you may ask? Why is GG the firstMetroidvania ever to touch my jaded gamerâ€™s soul? First, the physics aretop-notch; and you know how crucial that element is to me as far as Platformersare concerned. Secondly, the party dynamics are absolutely amazing; neverbefore have I handled a pair of MCs that so perfectly complement and complete eachother. Thirdly, the music, graphics and overall atmosphere are downrightsplendid. Last but not least, the progression curve is darn satisfying: GGis challenging without being unfair, and I could feel myself gettingstronger, sharper and better as I replayed the demo.Â Â Â Well,thatâ€™s a New Classic all right! title: The New Classics Sessions: Switch, Session 6

Thegraphics are splendid, with a lovely parallax effect and a striking contrastbetween the heroineâ€™s white, glowing sprite and the layered darkness of thedÃ©cor. Do I love that game? Ooooh yes I do, folks!Â Â Â Harvestella: It looks really darn pretty, that I must admit; and the characterdesign is right up my alley. Alas, combat is too slow and clunky for my taste;and the farming simulation drags on too much to keep me focused. Isuck so much at Platformers that I simply need perfect controls andphysics â€” not only to enjoy myself, but also to be able to play the darn game atall.Â Â Â Tasomachiâ€“ Behind the Twilight: Hereâ€™s another weirdJapanese indie developed and published by entities no one ever heard of â€” notthat itâ€™s a bad thing at all, mind ya. You know I just hate when a game playscoy or hard-to-get, and makes me jump through hoops to gain the very right to playit; and so, SF has to go.Â Â DarkSouls Remastered: So, we have slow movement andclunky controls, paired with deadly foes that somehow seem much faster than usâ€” despite operating in the same world, and presumably experiencing the samephysics as our MC. Some call this a thrilling challenge, and more power tothem; I call that fake difficulty, and to the pawn shop DSR goes.Â Â Â Bayonetta3: After my immediate crush on the second entry, Iassumed the third would pass with flying colours; alas, itâ€™s not so simple.First, Iâ€™m really not fond of the gloomy apocalyptic setting; secondly, theâ€˜transforming into demonsâ€™ gimmick makes combat too fussy for my taste. I kinda liked the little I played; and although I still havereservations, I definitely wanna see â€” and play â€” more of Brigandine.Â Prinny Presents NIS Classic â€“ Volume 1: Namely, weâ€™re dealing with Phantom Brave and Soul Nomad,two PSP RPGs. Not just mere RPGs, mind you: SRPGs.Very clunky, old-fashioned, molasses-like SRPGs. I donâ€™t think I need toexplain why that duo wonâ€™t join The Collection.Â Â Â Â RPG Maker MV: The Switch Lite screen is a bit too tiny for that kind of RPGbuilder, which would feel more at home on a big fat TV screen. title: The New Classics Sessions: Switch, Session 4

Creating my own shitty friend was fun, running at breakneck speedthrough revamped zones was fun, and the lush graphics and bright coloursenchanted my retinas â€” and heck, I just want more.Â Â Team Sonic Racing: I bought that game hoping to relive my Sonic Drift Racing days; unfortunately,that didnâ€™t happen. Sonic Drift Racingwas simple and clear-cut, with straightforward physics and short thematictracks; Team Sonic Racing has iffyphysics and long tracks with little to no discernible themes. Sonic Drift Racing this is not indeed â€” and I donâ€™t quite like what it is.Â Â Saviors of Sapphire Wings / Stranger ofSword City: Two ExperienceInc. FPDCs for the price of one! How did we get so lucky? Seriously though, Iâ€™moverjoyed. Iâ€™ve wanted to play the former â€” known inJapan as Students of the Round â€” sincemy fellow gamer and blogger Kina wrote a series of mouth-watering posts about it; as for the latter, Iâ€™ve wanted to play it since I purchased the Vitaversion. Yup, I bought SoSC twice,and Iâ€™m not even salty about it. Take my money, Experience Inc!Â Nexomon â€“ Extinction: If that game were a person, I would dropeverything in a heartbeat to follow them to the end of the world. These lushgraphics! These vibrant colours! Those adorable starters! That heart-warmingatmosphere! This is too much! Mygamerâ€™s heart is throbbing with giddiness and happiness, and I just cannot waitto go back to NE for good.Â Â Â Â Vambrace â€“ Cold Soul: Did someone say â€˜winter themeâ€™? Iâ€™m sold!Seriously though, that game has atmosphere in spades and a promising gameplay,and my gaming instinct wants more of it.Â Â KILL la KILL â€“ IF: The anime piqued my interest back in the days,but letâ€™s be honest: Iâ€™m not an anime aficionado, and Iâ€™ll probably never watchit. On the other hand, I can get the next best thing: a brawler featuring the KlaK crew and a piece of story! Andsince that particular brawler boasts some particularly stellar physics andgorgeous graphics, Iâ€™d be crazy not to indulge in it.Â Â Â I am Setsuna: Iâ€™m a complete and total sucker for wintry & snowy settings andatmosphere â€” so of course, I had to have a complete and total crush on Setsuna. The fighting system ainâ€™t half- bad either, and thecrawling is promising â€” really, no complaints at all here.Â Â Kowloon High-School Chronicles: I expected a Point&click with strong VN elements, taking placein a modern Korean setting. What I got instead was a first-person dungeoncrawler with a strong emphasis on puzzles â€” and a much unexpected Egyptiantemple setting. I was too disoriented by that mighty plot twist to sort out myimmediate feelings about KHSC; butIâ€™ll be damned if I donâ€™t give every FPDC that crosses my path its fair chanceto shine.Â Â Â Moero Crystal H: Itâ€™s moreof the same delightfully bonkers and risquÃ© GenkaiToki fare â€” only better than in Moe Chronicles. Weâ€™ll see â€”because that game is here to stay!Â Â Â Okami HD: A PS2 and Wii cultclassic thatâ€™s been ported to new machines over time â€” yet somehow nevermanaged to be a commercial hit despite garnering critical acclaim. Iâ€™ve wantedto try that game for years; yet now that the deed is done, Iâ€™m a bitunderwhelmed. Is it the weird, stiff camera angles? Is it the ever-so-slightlyclunky controls? title: The New Classics: Progress Report #4

Myinitial goal was to find my own cult classics, games I could adore and replayfor all eternity; then I realised that some games I adored could beonce-in-a-lifetime experiences. And thus comes my revamped goal: to spot thegames I really want to play â€” once, or a million times.Â Â That sounds like a no-brainer of a goal; but letâ€™s face it, I had toovercome a number of roadblocks to reach such a level of clarity andconfidence. I got rid of my gaming FOMO, I put to rest the fear of scarcityinherited from my early gaming years, I eradicated the sunk-cost fallacy andthe need to recoup all my gaming investments, I reined in my tendency to over-adaptand â€˜find some goodâ€™ in every single game; and most importantly, I learnt totrust my gaming instinct, fully and completely.Â Â Â With that new focus come two adjustments:Â â€” Puzzlegames Ã  la Professor Layton are now officially out of the New Classicoperation. The reason is simple: although Iâ€™ve never, ever been disappointed bya puzzle game, Iâ€™ve also never, ever felt the need to replay a single one ofthem once the deed was done. From now on, all puzzle games are â€˜games I wannaplay onceâ€™ â€” and Iâ€™m gonna play them for sure, and pawn them once Iâ€™m done.Â Â â€” VNs andotomes will get the New Classic treatment as well, contrary to what I announcedin the early stages of the operation. Iâ€™lldedicate a special session to these games, and go over all of them at once, regardlessof their host system.Â Â Â As for the current state of affairs: Iâ€™m proud to announce that my wholecurrent Switch collection has been put to the New Classic test! Iâ€™m currently going through my 3DS collection, and progressingfast; youâ€™ll get the reports in due time â€” namely, once Iâ€™m done unleashing mySwitch reports onto the world. Said unleashing will follow that report; Iâ€™llwrap things up with a celebratory post of sorts, and Iâ€™ll do the same for everysub-collection once Iâ€™m done with it. Â But wait,I hear you say; isnâ€™t the New Classic operation still a work in progress as faras the Switch is concerned? Yeah, about thatâ€¦ As unlikely as it may sound, Iâ€™mcurrently not feeling the slightest need to purchase new Switch releases. Icannot promise it wonâ€™t happen at some point this year; but for now, my gaminginstinct is dead-set on the New Classic operation and doesnâ€™t feel likepursuing new titles.Â Thatâ€™sall for that 4th New Classic Progress Report, dear fellow gamers! title: The New Classics #72: NieR: Automata â€“ The End of YoRHa
text: The backstory: I would lieif I claimed Iâ€™m a fan of Yoko Taroâ€™s universe and themes de predilection;on the other hand, I can safely claim Iâ€™ve always wanted to play Drakengardand NieR. So, imagine my joy when NieR: Automata suddenly poppedup on the Switch! I swear, that console made so many of my port&remakedreams come true that Iâ€™ll soon build a shrine to it. Maybe Drakengardwill grace the Switch on day as well? (Insert twinkling, starry eyes)Â Â The game: Anybody whoplayed NA knows that it starts with an in medias res introductionthat lasts roughly one hour. You cannot save during that intro; on the otherhand, you get to fight and explore a lot, before the game wraps things up withan epic boss fight. Then, youâ€™re sent to the main hub, and to the game per se.Â Â Â I couldsay that this intro is one of the best video game introductions Iâ€™ve everplayed, and that would be totally true. But thatâ€™s not all: that one-hoursequence is actually one of the best games Iâ€™ve ever played.Â Â Â Look: Iâ€™mgonna spill my guts here, and Iâ€™m gonna spill them hard. NAâ€™sintro awed me all the way through with its grandiose vistas, its masterfullyhandled cinematography, the very scope of its game world. I felt reverence,wonderment, astonishment, and all sorts of raw emotions I cannot put into words. I gaped atthe screen, I squealed in delight; I shook with fear, I shivered withexcitement; I beamed, I teared up â€” and I felt sheer joy, from beginningto end. There were times I was utterly in control, bristling with power; andthere were times I was overwhelmed, facing my own lack of skill and prowess â€”and both feelings were amazing. Never before did I feel such an intense,complete immersion in a game world; never before did I feel so much that I wasthe MC, that the game world was real. It doesnâ€™t matter that I onlytouched the tip of the iceberg when it comes to mastering the controls: I was fullythere, body and soul, alone with the game and my feelings â€” heck, I was thegame.Â Â Â Do youthink this paean is a complete emotional mess, dear fellow gamers? I totallyagree. NAâ€™s introduction did things to me; it roused my gamerâ€™ssoul in a way no other game ever did, and awoke emotions I had never feltbefore while playing.Â Â Â I wasstill basking in these glorious emotions when I cleared the intro and accessedthe main hub. I saved there, and kept playing. Then, something mighty weirdhappened: I enjoyed myself less. That magic I felt during the introduction wasgone, and gameplay suddenly felt moreâ€¦ tedious, somehow. Not only that, but Iexperienced my first Game Over!Â Â Â So, whathappened? I honestly donâ€™t know. Maybe NA is a game tailored for short playingsessions; after all, its gameplay is quite demanding, and can be taxing despitebeing immensely fulfilling. It could also be the fact that while NAâ€™sintroduction is quite linear, its first core section is much more open,requiring more exploration and finding oneâ€™s way. It could also be that thecore game is actually harder than the intro â€” I mean, why else would Ihave landed a Game Over?Â Â Â Iâ€™ll letyou on a little secret: I was initially planning to play the whole thing in onego after my immense crush on the intro, writing raving posts as I went on. However,my experience with NAâ€™s first core session made me reconsider. And so, Ijust wrote that New Classic post about it; and Iâ€™m gonna leave it at that fornow.Â  Â Â Â The verdict: Iâ€™ve notplayed enough to pass a fair judgement on Nier: Automataâ€™s coregameplay, so Iâ€™ll abstain until further play. I know one thing for sure,though: I absolutely adored the introduction, and I consider it afull-blown game. I mean, it has a narrative arc, a game world, plenty ofrunning around and fighting, a middle boss and an epic final boss â€” I donâ€™tneed more in me RPG, folks! That introduction alone is worth replaying over andover, and is enough to grant NA a spot in The Collection â€” regardless ofmy future feelings about the rest of the game. Thatâ€™s a pretty weird situation,I must admit; but the gaming instinct wants what it wants, baby!

title: The New Classics #65: Streets of Rage 4
text: The Backstory: I didnâ€™t play the second, nor did I play the third; but the veryfirst Streets of Rage was a major highlight of my childhood andteenage gaming years â€” so of course I had to buythat unhoped-for Switch entry!Â Â  The Game: Back in the days, Blaze was the go-to character: she was fast, shejumped high, and she was hawt to book â€” allthings that perfectly compensated her lack of punching power. For one, itâ€™s easier to scour the eponymous streets of rage witha fellow player than on your own; for another, fighting is highly technicalbehind its apparent simplicity, and you can soon fight yourself overwhelmed ifyouâ€™re not fast enough and/or if you donâ€™t master the controls. It wasnâ€™t long before all my SoRautomatisms came back to the surface â€” grabbing foes from behind, landing onyour feet while being thrown in the air, jump-kicking, you name it. The gamecleverly opens on a recreation of SoRâ€™s first level â€” those gritty,dirty streets, which are just as iconic to a SoR fan as Green Hillto a Sonic fan â€” yet quickly enriches the experience by adding nifty,atmospheric new elements such as a subway wagon.Â Â As for the novelties, theyâ€™re mostly on the cute,cosmetic side â€” but not only. You can now choose what kind of food youâ€™ll find lying around â€” I had to pick up croissants, obviously â€” as well as access brand-newspecial attacks and combos. Gone is the possibility to call yourfellow coppers to clear the way; and I was pretty miffed not to findmulticoloured Noras strutting their stuff and cracking their whips.Â Â Â The Verdict: Sure, Streets of Rage cannot be as cultish to me as it usedto be; but Iâ€™ll be damned if I donâ€™t hold onto that fourth entry and make themost of it. title: The New Classics #61: Hyper Light Drifter

title: The New Classics #53: Shovel Knight â€“ Treasure Trove
text: The Backstory: No need to present ShovelKnight: that runaway success has been making Yacht Club Gamesâ€™ fortunesince 2014, and keeps doing so as itâ€™s ported to every platform under thegaming sun. title: The New Classics #26: Nelke & the Legendary Alchemists
text: The Backstory: That Atelier spinoff got a lot of flak forstraying from the seriesâ€™ classic formula andfor being too simple and repetitive. I personally have no issue with a spinoffnot emulating its seriesâ€™ core gameplay â€” I mean,thatâ€™s the very point of spinoffs â€” especially when said series happens to be Atelier. As for simple and repetitivegameplay, I like it as a rule â€” providing that the loop is satisfying. Andanyway, my gaming instinct claimed Nelkedespite the lukewarm reviews, and thatâ€™s the only reason I need to play a game.Â Â The Game: Atelier fan service for the faithful isthe name of the game here, as Nelkestars a coterie of famous alchemists from all entries and their sidekicks. Iwouldnâ€™t notice this, though, because: a) I skipped all cutscenes, and b) thenumber of Atelier games Iâ€™ve playedcan still be counted on the fingers of one hand. I have to question the logicof that decision, though: is a spinoff the best place to pay homage to a seriesby bringing its full cast? Why not create a dedicated celebratory game starringthe whole crew and the trademark Atelier gameplay? The way I see it, Nelke is trying to appeal to Atelier aficionados with its cast, whileshooting itself in the foot with a gameplay that is bound to sit poorly with any long-time Atelier fan.Â Â Â Â Talking about the gameplay, reviews led me to believe that explorationwas entirely automatic, with no input whatsoever from the player. Well, Iâ€™mglad â€” andrelieved â€” to tell youthat itâ€™s not (entirely) the case. Foragingis now automatic: instead of scouring every corner of wild areas, you watchyour crew run on a path and pocket stuff at random. I can understand the ire ofAtelier fans, and why such adeparture from the classic formula would feel like complete heresy; however, Imust admit that new style doesnâ€™t bother me in the slightest. I actually like it: itâ€™s fast, efficient andsynthetic â€” the Atelier basics in a nutshell.Â Â Combat, on the other hand, is still fully controlled by the player. You canimagine how overjoyed I was, as fighting is one of my favourite features in Atelier games; but then again, Iunderstand how Atelier fans could beroyally pissed off. So you keep something that appears in basically every RPGunder the sun, yet you oust something that is intrinsic to the Atelier formula? Weird choice indeed,Gust.Â Â Â But then again, weâ€™re technically not dealing with an Atelier game. Itâ€™s not called â€˜Atelier Nelkeâ€™, but simply â€˜Nelkeâ€™; and Nelke is not an alchemist,sheâ€™s an urban developer-meets-mayor. The player walking in her snug boots issupposed to organise everything and assign tasks to lackeys helpers,rather than do the deed themselves. This gives Nelkeâ€™s gameplay a dry, nearly abstract quality very reminiscent ofmanagement games; yet the sheer speedand slickness of the gameplay loop screams â€˜phone gameâ€™. All in all, Nelke is a weird mix, a game thatdoesnâ€™t know which audience it wants to grab â€” now, does it grab me?Â Â Â The Verdict: Well,colour me surprised: I actually like that game! My gaming instinct is playingsmug and chuckling â€˜I told you so!â€™; but honestly, I wasnâ€™t so convinced atfirst. I wonâ€™t claim I had the mightiest crush on Nelke; but I certainly like it enough to hold onto it and play moreof it later.

title: Fuga â€“ Melodies of Steel: Can a digital-only release ruin a gameâ€™s career?
text: After playing Solatorobo, I got curious about the Little TailBronx series it hails from. A bit of research revealed the existence of a veryrecent game in the series: a 2021 release called Fuga: Memories of Steel,which acts as a prequel to Solatorobo and garnered highly favourablereviews from critics and players alike. More research revealed some potentiallyinteresting gameplay mixing elements of SRPG, shooting game and roguelike, aswell as a complex narrative and rich universe. Even more research uncovered thefact that Fuga cost a whopping 2,5 million euros, and was yet notprofitable in December 2021, with sales reaching only a mere million euros. Â Such a combination of events was a mystery to me. How could a highlypraised game released on virtually every gaming system available at the timeperform so poorly? While pondering that mystery, I proceeded to purchase Fuga;my interest was piqued, and I wanted to secure it after my short yet glowingexperience with Solatorobo. I quickly discovered that no physicalrelease existed, neither for the Switch nor for any other system; and thus I headedto the Nintendo eShop. But once there, my purchasing impulses were eradicatedon the spot by the gameâ€™s price tags: Fuga requires you to fork out 40euros for its normal edition, and no less than 60 euros for its deluxe edition â€” with no demoincluded, b*tch.Â Â Â Weâ€™re basically talking about a digital game that costs as much as aphysical game â€” not just on the Switch, but on every platform itâ€™s been released on. Sucha setting is pretty common; however, it mostly applies to major games that alsohave a physical version â€” with physical being the main release channel. Digital-onlygames tend to be cheaper as a rule, and for good reason: not only are theyoften simpler than games that get a physical release, but they also usually donâ€™ttarget the same audience. And here, I think, lies the main reason Fugasells so poorly: CyberConnect2 simply chose the wrong distribution channel forit, and missed on most of its intended target audience by doing so.Â  Â Letâ€™s check the facts, folks: weâ€™re dealing with a game belonging to aconfidential series, with an original and potentially complex gameplay and adeep, heavy story that clashes with the overall cutesy graphics. This is a veryniche proposition; and typically, niche gaming aficionados also favour physicalgames. This is not an absolute law; yet the correlation is very strong.Look no further than yours truly to find an example of it: Iâ€™d have secured aphysical version of Fuga in a heartbeat, but Iâ€™m balking at the thoughtof buying it digital. And mind you, Iâ€™m not the only one: some fellow gamersexpressed the same sentiment in comments in the article I linked above.Â Â Â There is no doubt that Fuga lost some sales because of itsdigital-only release, and is probably still losing some as we speak. Itâ€™simpossible to tell how many; but it may be enough to hurt its career and legacyon the long run. Incidentally, no physical release means less visibility, whichonly makes matters worse. At that point, the best thing CyberConnect2 could doto salvage Fuga would be to release a physical version, and to advertiseit the best they could; otherwise, Iâ€™m afraid this game will simply fly underthe radar and disappear quietly. Â Iâ€™d really, really like to play Fuga. Thereâ€™s a 25% discount onit as Iâ€™m writing this; but is it enough to convince me to cross thedigital-only Rubicon? Iâ€™m not sure, honestly. I still have a couple of days toponder the matter; but regardless of my final decision, my hesitation speaksvolumes about the impact of the distribution channel on a gameâ€™s sales. Had Fugabeen granted a physical release, the cartridge would already be in mycollection â€” and mymoney in CyberConnect2â€™s pockets; instead, Iâ€™m agonizing about whether or not Ishould buy it, and I may end up not doing so. Thatâ€™s a pity, as I love nothingmore than to support little-known developers producing niche works of love; buthonestly, CyberConnect2 kinda shot themselves in the foot with this one.

title: The New Classics #23: Neptunia x Senran Kagura â€“ Ninja Wars
text: The Backstory: This is acomplete case of â€˜shut up and take my moneyâ€™. title: The New Classics #22: 13 Sentinels â€“ Aegis Rim
text: The Backstory: â€˜Chaoticâ€™is an apt word to describe 13 Sentinelsâ€™release journey. title: The New Classics #21: Record of Lodoss War â€“ Deedlit in Wonder Labyrinth

title: The New Classics #20: Seven Pirates H
text: The Backstory: The Genkai Tokki series is a weird beast; Iâ€™m not sure I fully graspthe way it operates, but hereâ€™s what Iâ€™m sure about. Felistella and/or CompileHeart are always involved one way or another; the series explores several RPGsubgenres through dedicated threads; and, last but not least, each and everyentry proudly boasts outrageous amounts of fan service. After a skippable introductory cutscene, I was let loose inthe game world, free to slaughter respawnable foes to my heartâ€™s content. Oh,the absolute joy! The gameplay loop is simple, yet quite complete andaddictive. On top of tiny dungeons Ã  la Hyperdimension Neptunia andbasic turn-based combat with (beautifully animated) super-skills, the gameoffers side quests, harvesting and crafting options and, last but not least,the seriesâ€™ trademark â€” a fan-servicey stat-raising feature! I may well follow thething once I play the game for real, though; Moe Chronicleâ€™s pervy storyturned out to be surprisingly thoughtful and touching, so maybe 7PHâ€™sstory packs some pleasant surprises as well.Â Â One thing I didnâ€™t expect from that game, and got nonetheless, is amodicum of strategic depth. The very first boss battle â€” which happens roughly five minutes afterstarting the game, en passant â€” is hardly winneable unless you unleash your super skill. Said superskill becomes available one the associated gauge reaches 200; the best courseof action is thus to fill up the gauge to roughly 190 through random battlesbefore proceeding to the boss fight. Like, should you have thewhole crew gang up on the boss, or should you let only one or two units attackswhile the rest defends, in order to rack up points for triggering super skills?It all boils down to your playing style, really. 7PH seems to be an easygame, as fan-servicey titles should be as far as Iâ€™m concerned; I may be wrong,but I donâ€™t think this game will ever punish you for not sticking to a veryprecise course of action.Â Â Last but not least, 7PH is a heart-warming game. Not only is itvisually appealing, with its bright and vibrant colours, but itâ€™s also lively, saucyand zesty. It doesnâ€™t take itself too seriously, and itâ€™s obviously intent onmaking the player happy; I love such intentions, and Iâ€™d be more than enjoysome quality time with 7PH.Â Â Â The Verdict: I had aninkling I was going to love that game; however, I didnâ€™t anticipate how frigginâ€™ much I would love it. title: The New Classics #19: Crown Trick
text: The Backstory: A cutelittle roguelike that unexpectedly got granted a physical release â€” with a specialedition, please. title: The New Classics #16: Tactics Ogre
text: The Backstory: TacticsOgre was the very first game I purchased for my brand-new PSP, way back in2013. Mind you, it would havestayed untouched for even longer if not for my fellow gamer Siegâ€™s prompt toplay it; now the deed is done, and here come my impressions. title: All the games I adored, yet wonâ€™t play again
text: I promised it not so long ago, and here it comes! I thought thesegames were Cult Classics of Mine, because I enjoyed playing them so darn much;but I realise now that they were actually once-in-a-lifetime experiences â€” which is mighty fine too. And so Iâ€™ll part with them, with a fewwords as a heartfelt goodbye!Â Final Fantasy Legend II: That spinoff was oneof my most memorable Game Boy runs â€” a feat made all the more memorable by thefact that I didnâ€™t play it as a starry-eyed kid in 1991, but rather as aseasoned RPG aficionado in 2014. It was a mad challenge that I totallyrelished; but I also remember that it roughed me up like crazy, and that I camevery close to quitting a couple of times. I didnâ€™t complain at the time; but Isure as heck donâ€™t want to relive the whole thing either.Â Â Â Shiren the Wanderer: I had the most amazing time withthe first Shiren entry. It was an epic ride full of elation and despair,joy and sorrow. The highs were deliriously high, the lows were soul-crushinglylow; and I can safely claim that very few games Iâ€™ve played were such arollercoaster of feels. Any second run of Shiren would pale compared tothat first one â€” and heck, I really donâ€™t want to endure such brutality again. Â Â Legacyof Ys â€“ Books I&II / Ys I&II Chronicles: Playing that pair delighted both the gaming historian and the ARPGaficionado in me. However, I have to face the truth: not only have I forgottennearly everything about these games, but they also cannot hold a candle toother ARPGs and Hackâ€™nâ€™Slashes that are Cult Classics of Mine.Â Â  Â Final Fantasy: The original Final Fantasywas a delirious grinding fest from beginning to end, and I completely lapped itup. However, as far as grindy turn-based RPGs go, I can think of a thousandtitles that Iâ€™d rather play â€” starting with my whole posse of Kemco budget RPGs.Â Â Â Popolocrois: I absolutely adored that game back in thedays. It was lovely and heart-warming, with a sweet nostalgic atmosphere thatstayed with me long after I finished it. Playing it made me feel good, and Icannot remember a single thing that bothered or annoyed me. For the longesttime, I kinda wanted to replay it; but that desire is now gone, and I donâ€™tthink it will ever come back.Â  Â Â Â Rivieraâ€“ The Promised Land: Just like Popolocrois,Riviera really charmed the pants off me when I played it. It wasabsolutely unique back in the days, and still is; I loved every minute of it,and I donâ€™t have a single negative thing to say about it. I wrote an amazinglylong post about that first Dept. Heaven offering, and it still has plenty tooffer me; and yet, I never felt even the slightest urge to replay it once myrun was over, and I still donâ€™t.Â   Â Astonishia Story: Man, I owe a lot to that game.It was the first game to awaken my gaming ferweh after my Second Coming of Gaming, and one of very few modern games that awoke the raw emotions I usedto feel when I started gaming (other such games being Legend of Legacyand Arc of Alchemist). That first run was truly magical; and Iâ€™mafraid any subsequent run would feel more mundane, and only serve to revealsome flaws while bringing nothing of value to my gamersâ€™ soul.Â Â Â Trails in the Sky: I should have hated that game forits slow, strategy-infused combat, its indolent pacing and its emphasis onstory; and yet, a miracle somehow happened, and I ended up adoring it. Like,really frigginâ€™ adoring it. I still feel mushy just thinking of it; but I alsofeel just as strongly that I shouldnâ€™t ever come close to it again.Â Â Â MoeChronicles: I had some darn good fun withthat game. However, and despite my undying love for FPDCs, I donâ€™t feellike replaying it, ever. Iâ€™d gladly lose myself again in The Lost Child,Dungeon Travelers 2 or Demon Gaze; but Moe Chroniclesleans more on the Class of Heroes side â€” an acquired taste that I canlive without.Â Â Bravely Default: Definitely one of the most intenselyoriginal and memorable RPGs Iâ€™ve played, boasting what is probably my favouriteclass system of all times (coming from someone who dislike class systems as arule). Unforgettable aesthetics and atmosphere, and the most insane boss rushIâ€™ve ever tackled. Heck, just writing all this makes me wanna play BravelyDefault again; and yet, deep down, I know Iâ€™ll never get down toit.Â Â Â Â Legend of Legacy: Playing that game was a deeplymoving experience for me: it offered me acompletely unique mix of feels, impressions and emotions I neverencountered in any game before, or since. And yet, something is lacking;something that could make me wanna play Legend of Legacy again. The oldme would have tried to analyse what that â€˜somethingâ€™ was, but the new me knowsthat it wonâ€™t change jack sh*t â€” and so, Iâ€™ll just accept these feelings andmove on.Â Thatâ€™sall for the time being; but who knows, maybe other games will join that club,as I realise over time that I donâ€™t wanna replay them despite loving them topieces. At any rate, Iâ€™m happy I can now feel that way about a game: it meansthat Iâ€™m finally reaching a place of solace in my gaming career, and that Iâ€™mdone with the need to cling obsessively to every single game I love. Some are meantto be lifelong companions, some are meant to stick around for a while, and someare meant to be cameos â€” and hey, itâ€™s mighty fine that way!

title: Dabbling in Demos: Monster Hunter Rise â€“ Sunbreak
text: My first foray into the legendary monster-slaughtering series didnâ€™t go well. I steered clear of it after that, only daring to purchase a couple ofspinoffs I have yet to play; but for some reason, my gaming instinct suddenlywanted to try the thing again after seven years. I know better than to fightthe gaming instinctâ€™s flights of fancy; however, years of gaming purchases havemade me wiser, and I reasoned than a demo would be more than enough to satiatemy gaming instinctâ€™s curiosity.Â A few hours later, I found myself playing the demo for the newest Riseextension â€” which you can play without owning Rise,surprisingly enough. I picked a randomcharacter that looked good â€” fickle gamer is fickle â€”and proceeded to find the beast I was ordered to slaughter. The game describedthat hunt as a mission for beginners, and I was fully confident I could do thedeed.Â Â Twothings immediately blew my mind. The first is that you can go absolutely anywhere,and you donâ€™t die from high falls â€” Iâ€™m rolling my eyes at you, Breath ofthe Wild. I donâ€™t like open worlds as a rule; but I have to admit that360-degree roaming is a thing of beauty and awesomeness. Itâ€™s not like reallife, itâ€™s better than real life, because real-life physics wonâ€™t letyou perform the kind of stunts Sunbreak allows â€” like, I was sure asheck that reckless jump down a waterfall would kill me; but I landed safe andsound, and could run right away like nothing had happened.Â Â Â The second thing that blew my mind is how darn sluggish thephysics are. Are you kidding me, Capcom? Am I really supposed to hunt wildbeasts with such slow reflexes? My character felt like a ten-tonne truck â€” or, more precisely, it felt like what it actually was: acreature trying to run while decked in a full set of armour and carrying a hugesword on its back. The thing is, I hate when developers play itrealistic with some parts of a gameâ€™s physics while making other partscompletely bonkers. This is the Valkyria Chronicles 4 story allover again; why on earth implement no-damage jump, if youâ€™re going to ruin itwith impeded sprint?Â Â Â  Rantingsabout physics aside, it took me five real-life minutes to reach the beast ofinterest. I donâ€™t fancy running around for minutes in RPGs â€” and I fancy iteven less when I get knocked out cold after thirty seconds of tedious fighting.Why, thank you, game! I blame my resounding defeat on the aforementionedsluggish physics â€” even though deep down, I know my shitty motor skills and exclusivelove for lightning-fast real-time combat are to blame. I have neither theability nor the desire to master Monster Hunterâ€™s deliberate and leadenbrand of physics â€” as a matter of fact, I didnâ€™t even give the mission a secondtry.Â Â The end!Â MonsterHunter Rise is a gorgeous game for sure; but justlike its predecessor, itâ€™s clearly not made for me. I have good hopes that the Storiesspinoffs will suit me better, though â€” good thing I have them lined up for theNew Classic test! Iâ€™ll see you later with plenty of gaming goodness, dearfellow gamers; in the meantime, keep doing your thing and take care!

title: The New Classics #14: Castlevania: The Dracula X Chronicles
text: The Backstory: Do I needto present Castlevania? Of course I donâ€™t. What I need to mention, onthe other hand, is that CDXC is my very first foray into that mythicalseries. title: The New Classics: Progress Report #3

title: Ducktales: Itâ€™s a rich duckâ€™s world
text: Aaah, Ducktales. My thirdGame Boy game, which came to join my budding collection right after Super Mario Land and Bugs Bunny Crazy Castle. The thing is, I cannot reliably polish off Ducktales,even after all these years and runs; there is simply no telling whether Iâ€™llfeast my eyes on the final boss when I boot up the game. See, Ducktalesis really not that easy. One reason is that just like its MC, this gameis real stingy: there is no Continue whatsoever, extra lives are a precious fewand viciously hidden, and you start with a measly three lives and three HPpoints. You can reap two hidden HP points over the course of your adventure,and the game is a tad more forgiving if you play in Easy Mode; however, thatainâ€™t enough to guarantee a smooth run, let alone a successful one.Â Indeed, there is a worse hindrance at work in that game: the jumps,folks. Ducktales boasts pretty tight and reliable controls overall â€” which makes theviciousness of the jumps all the more blatant. These jumps are designedto be deadly, to act as run-enders; and man, do they excel at that nastyjob. Not every single jump in Ducktales is potentially fatal, mind you;just a chosen few of them â€” which makes them all the more horribly memorable. Every level has atleast one series of such jumps: the Flagada Jones ride in the Amazon, the wagontrip in Transylvania, the chasms in the African Mines, the crevasses in TheHimalayas â€” and lastbut not least, the blocks on the Moon. Oh gosh, those blocks. Manya hope of a successful run died on these blocks back in the days, and theysingle-handedly destroyed a couple of promising recent runs â€” that is, until Ihad an epiphany and suddenly remembered the existence of that secret passageat the right of the remote control room, which allows you to bypass thoseblocks entirely. And gosh, the way that memory emerged from the deepestrecesses of my mind was so darn satisfying.Â Â Â  Did the jumps in Ducktales kinda traumatize me? You bet! Butfortunately, there is more to that game than nasty jumps. There is a kickasssoundtrack, an awesome atmosphere, and great controls; and last but not least,there is the thrill of collecting diamonds and treasures all around the world Ã la Indiana Jones. Ducktales is not stingy with items, thatâ€™s for sure:the whole game is full to the brim with stuff hidden everywhere â€” in safes andblocks, but also in scenery elements, and even in thin air. Hitting tree stumpsand graves with your walking stick produces diamonds (and sometimes foes), andjumping around can make items pop into existence. The whole treasure-searchingtheme is so ingrained in Ducktales that the usual score is replaced by amoney count, which increases as you greedily pocket gems and treasures;not only does is that design choice more engaging that a mere, abstract score,but itâ€™s perfectly consistent with the gameâ€™s MC and the seriesâ€™ spirit. Cherryon the cake: if you collect ten million dollars, youâ€™ll be rewarded by a finalscene showing Scrooge McDuck jumping with joy next to a giant safe overflowingwith diamonds â€” needless to say, I lapped up that scene as a kid.Â Â And I played an extra run just to see that scene again.Â Long story short: I loved that game back in the days, and Istill do. Itâ€™s not as easy as Iâ€™d like, and it still roughs me up more than Iâ€™dwish; but I have a fondness for it, a fondness that will probably endure untilmy dying day. Itâ€™s an unforgettable part of not only my gaming career, but alsomy childhood; and it remains my favourite licensed game ever.Iâ€™ll see you again, Scrooge McDuck â€” and so will I see you soon with more gaminggoodness, dear fellow gamers!

title: The New Classics #9: Death End re;Quest
text: The Backstory: I wantedCompile Heart and Idea Factory to bring the Switch version of Death Endre;Quest to our shores. The fighting system is similar to the HyperdimensionNeptunia one, as each party member can move around in a fighting arena andhas a defined attack range; however, the emphasis on turn-based and strategyelements is much stronger than in HN. You can choose three actions foreach party member at the beginning of a turn; you then position your characterthe way you want, and unleash the three actions. Add to this a pool-like mechanic (that involves knocking back foesagainst each other or against the arenaâ€™s boundaries) and special ground tiles that can beused to trigger transformations in party members, and you get a deep, complexand engaging fighting system that begs to be mastered to the fullest. You gaina level every two to four battles, depending on the number and levels of foes.By the time I hit the two-hours mark, my team of two boasted a pretty decentLv.20. â€” just asgood as Emboar reaching Lv.30 after three hours. Iâ€™m totally aware I wouldnâ€™thave reached that level after a mere two hours of play if I hadnâ€™t skipped allthe VN elements; however, it means that the grinding potential is there. Â Â Â Still, that sweet grindiness doesnâ€™t make me blind to the gameâ€™s flaws.For one, being stuck because I skipped a cutscene and some tutorials isa serious downside, and a potential deal-breaker. For another, I donâ€™t fancythe setting and the overall atmosphere. Shinaâ€™s world feels utterly generic,the kind of game world youâ€™ve seen in a million budget games before; and sodoes Arataâ€™s modern day Japan, which could have been lifted from basically anyVN. Lily Hopes reminds me a lot of another RPG character, but I cannot pinpointwhich one; and positioning in combat is sometimes a real chore.Â Â Â The Verdict: I love DeathEnd re;Questâ€™s combat; however, that alone is not enough to declare it aNew Classic. Still, not all hope is lost forthe series and for its amazing fighting system: I own the sequel, which seemsto sport a more distinctive atmosphere â€” and hopefully a couple of quality-of playimprovements. title: The New Classics #8: Kitaria Fables

title: The New Classics #6: Super Neptunia RPG
text: The Backstory: As araving Hyperdimension Neptunia fan, I obviously had to get my paws onthat 2.5D spinoff â€” despite its ridiculously uninspired title. Not only does said titlesound like the name of a vanilla SNES game, but itâ€™s also quite misleading.B*tch, all canon HN games are RPGs; if you wanna point out whatmakes SNRPG different from the rest of the crew, NeptuniaSidescrolling Galore or Super Neptunia Platformer would have beenbetter suited.Â Â Â The Game: Indeed, thePlatforming is strong with this one. I have nothing against some platformaction in my RPG, as my love for Astria Ascending proves; unfortunately,SNRPGâ€™s brand of platforming is far from being as stellar and deliciousas AAâ€™s one. The physics are wobbly at best and unreliable at worst â€” and when I sayâ€˜worstâ€™, I mean jumping. Itâ€™s unprecise as heck, with jumps being eithertoo short or too long. Not only that, but platforms have some slipperinessaround the edges that makes jumping even less reliable. I cannot count thenumber of times I fell from a platform because I landed too far on it andslipped on the other side, or because I tried to run and jump at the very edgeand slipped.Â Â Â Platforming is all nice and well (or not so much in that case), buthow does the RPG part fare? Well, letâ€™s say itâ€™s complicated. ArtisanStudios wanted to inject some exploration by allowing players to progress leftand right, but also up and down between side-scrolling sections â€” think Stage 1 of Platoonon the NES. Alas, that noble intent backfires on the player; with sectionsbeing very samey and dungeon maps very unprecise, itâ€™s all to easy to getconfused and lost. Mind you, the side-scrolling sections are obviously notmeant to be labyrinthine; they just end up feeling that way, because ofpoor level design.Â Â Â Combat could have been the gameâ€™s saving grace â€” and letâ€™s behonest, it was at first. Hitting the A, B, X or Y buttons at precise times totrigger one of the four party membersâ€™ regular attack was something I had neverencountered before; and it felt both nicely simple and pleasantly hypnotic.Flashier skills and better attacks were obviously on the way, and I expected anice roll with that fighting system; however, my enthusiasm died on the spotwhen the game forced me to use break attacks to get rid of an HP bag boss.Break attacks are triggered through the Break meter, which has to be filled byusing regular attacks; and it takes forever to fill it. It took me fifteenfrigginâ€™ minutes to clear that fight; fifteen minutes of hitting a foe thathealed every turn to fill my Break meter, being hit by attacks that dealt 3-4points of damage, healing when my HP got too low, and finally releasing a BreakAttack after what felt like a million hits. Zero challenge, total boredom. Thisis the complete antithesis of canon HN combat â€” all flashy skills, endlesscombos and fast-paced battles. Â Â Â The Verdict: We allknow where this is headed, dear fellow gamers: Super Neptunia RPG is byno means a New Classic of mine. It lacks everything I love in canon HNentries; and the things it brings are definitely not to my liking. Next please!

The only SRPGs Iâ€™ll hold onto are Fire EmblemEchoes, because itâ€™s short and I love the hackâ€™nâ€™slash sections too darn much;and Stingâ€™s Yggdra Union and Gungnir â€” because Dept. Heaven, b*tch. I will amend TheList soon enough; but the decision is taken, and itâ€™s taken for good. No FOMO tobe found; Iâ€™m actually relieved, and glad I went back to my RPG roots. Â Another important decision Iâ€™m going to enforce is to batch-test RPGseries. The very fact that I do own full series I have yet to try at allis absolutely ridiculous; I should have bought a single entry, played it, and purchasedthe rest only if I liked that first entry. Well, whatâ€™s done is done; and sinceI own these series, I might as well give them a try.
